body:
seems that it's also actual for 
`junit.jupiter.testclass.order.default = org.junit.jupiter.api.ClassOrderer$OrderAnnotation`
class with 
`@Order(DEFAULT)`
may run earlier than class with
`@Order(MAX_VALUE)`

@hikoma While classes are ordered during discovery with the configured "orderer", at execution time all test classes are submitted in this order to the underlying `ForkJoinPool`. In which order that will schedule them is outside of our control.

**Team decision:** Document that class ordering is not honored for parallel execution for top-level classes (similar to what's documented for `MethodOrderer`).

@marcphilipp Is it intended to work with `@Isolated`? And in the case of `@ResourceLock()` where the classes are executed in a parallel context but a specific ResourceLock "group" is run sequentially, will/is the order ensured for the sequential running classes? (if not, it would be awesome if that worked)

Does this mean the case explained above is just "luck to be in the right order"?
@marcphilipp I see, so that's what was going on. Thank you for taking the time to consider this issue.

@nbrugger-tgm It might work with `@Isolated`/`@ResourceLock` but that's also outside our control since the `ForkJoinPool` is in charge of scheduling tasks. It's unlikely that will change in a future version but I don't think we can guarantee that.
